title: Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Career and Migration
abstractText:
The aim of this seminar series was to provide a forum for stakeholders to address issues concerning career and migration and to develop knowledge/ practice in this area. To achieve these goals six one-day seminars were held involving participants from the UK, Europe, North America, including academics, policy shapers and practitioners. Each of the six events focused on a different dimension of the career/migration nexus.

Key findings:

  • the loss, recovery and reconstruction of career capital as pivotal in experiences of migration. Key emergent issues were: insecurity, security and their dynamic interplay
  • the centrality of relationships with family (in home and host countries), compatriots, communities in migrantsâ€™ career development
  • work and career as important to processes of acculturation
  • the salience of emotional dimensions - often overlooked in the literature
  • methodologies in research and practice: appropriateness of creative and narrative approaches for researching and supporting people in unfamiliar environments
  • migration takes many forms and some styles of international working (eg weekly commuting) blur the boundaries between international and intranational moves
  • individual and corporate goals frequently differ in the management of international assignees, and these discrepancies are rarely recognised, let alone resolved.
